Expectation1: Avoid gossiping or speaking negatively about others
Situation1: The acquaintance is in a group where people are talking about the recent decisions of a mutual colleague.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: I stood in the break room, coffee in hand, as the conversation turned to Mark’s recent decisions at work. As an acquaintance, I always tried to avoid gossip or speaking negatively about others, but the group’s laughter and pointed comments made it hard to stay silent or slip away unnoticed. My phone buzzed—a reminder that my volunteer shift started in fifteen minutes. I knew several other volunteers were already there and could easily cover for me if I was a little late, but I also prided myself on being reliable and punctual. The group looked at me, waiting for my opinion on Mark. I felt the pressure to join in, to fit in with the group, but I also felt the tug of responsibility to leave now and arrive on time for my shift. My mind raced, torn between the expectations of being a good acquaintance and a dependable volunteer, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
